entry.title: My journey at IKEA Digital Hub
entry.content:
Last year, I worked as a full-time Software Engineer Intern at IKEA for 10 months. My job was mainly delivering frontends for the IKEA WeChat SMP. I also contributed to the static webpage library for the APP/SMP team.

Project overview

The project I mainly worked on during my internship is called IKEA WeChat SMP.

I created reusable components like address selector, broadcast popups, configurable floating buttons, advertise card, etc. and I also designed and implemented product inventory module, optimized logic for delivery, live stream, checkout and coupons.

If you are a WeChat user, you can search for the IKEA WeChat SMP program in WeChat.

What we built is basically the online shopping center of IKEA integrated in WeChat, which is the most widely used (1.25 billion monthly active users) social app in China.

I was lucky enough to participate in the initial building work and witness the official nationwide launch of this project. This project achieved 6x,xxx average daily active users with 6xx.xK RMB average sales per day after the official launch.

A day in my life at IKEA

My work time is usually from 9:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday to Friday.

Morning routine: Stand-up meeting

Every morning when I arrive at our office building, our team will have a daily stand-up meeting to talk about our progress and check the obstacles in our work. It is usually about 10 minutes, and it marks the start of my day at work.

This is also my best chance to know about what other people in my team are working on. Gradually, I gained a more comprehensive understanding of the projects’ status in my team as well.

Sprint start: getting my tasks on JIRA

Since I worked in a Scrum team, we have sprints. A sprint is like an iteration period. A normal sprint is 2 weeks usually. When the sprint starts, we will have an Iteration (or Sprint) Planning Meeting (IPM). In this meeting, we will discuss how much of the backlog can be committed to and delivered in this sprint. The tasks will be evaluated in story points.

After the sprint starts, I will have several tasks on JIRA which show the work I need to get done in this sprint. I am also responsible to update my task status every day.

Sprint ongoing: develop, discuss, and deliver

During the sprint, I would discuss some ambiguous points with the Product Owner, and code to meet up the expectations. This process also includes a lot of conversations with the UI/UX designer, the Quality Assurance Engineer, the Backend Development Engineer, and even people from other teams or departments.

At first I was super shy and it was a big challenge for me to gather the courage to start conversations with so many people. It is because of how nice the people here are that makes me comfortable to express my opinion and become more and more confident.

When I think my code is ready, I would inform a QA Engineer to put my code into testing. When the testings are passed, and the PO thinks it fulfills the acceptance criteria, my code will go online to our shopping program for people to use.

Snacks are amazing!!

Here we have different kinds of snacks and fruit every day. I love the cheesecakes - I know it’s not that healthy - which are so beautiful and delicious. The kiwis here are always sweeter than the ones I brought from the market. And when there’s an activity or party, we have more. There are yogurt, bread, chocolate cake, fried chicken, meatballs, sausages, cookies, sushis, more than ten kinds of drinks…

Summary

2020 was definitely a special year for many people. For me as well.

Instead of pursuing my graduate study right after finishing my undergrad study as I originally planned, I was “forced” by COVID-19 to take a gap year and did my first formal internship in life. I was lucky enough to spend this year with people at IKEA.

I wanted to thank everyone in my team, who was the kindest person and most willing to answer my questions at any time. I also wanted to especially thank my line manager Leo and my mentor, Ciki, who perfected my internship.

When I first arrived at IKEA, I almost knew nothing about real-industry software development. Ciki was always happy to give me useful instructions and show me the right direction to work in.

It was a great time working here, and the people here were so welcoming and so supportive to me.

See you, IKEA!

entry.title: Quick Notes on Scrum Basics
entry.content:
Quick notes of the Linkedin Learning Course “Scrum: The Basics” by Kelley O’Connell, with my own experience in the workspace.

Problems to Solve

What does the Team’s BACKLOG contain?

A: a prioritized list of work that must be done

Select something Scrum Teams do at the end of every sprint.

A: Demonstrate the completed work.

In the Agile Manifesto, Scrum values _.

A: responding to change

The Heart of the Framework

Agile Project:

  • Product Owner
  • Scrum Master

What are the 3 normal project constraints?

time, cost, scope

What are two key Scrum roles?

Product Owner and Scrum Master

What do you use to establish ground rules with the Team?

Team Norms

Getting Ready to Work

Minimun Viable Product (MVP)

User Stories

As a , I want so that .

Acceptance Criteria (AC)

Iteration (or Sprint) Planning Meetings (IPM)

What do Scrum Teams use to break their work into small, deliverable elements?

User Stories

The Roadmap is meant to apply your work Themes over time.

TRUE

What types of estimation do Scrum Teams use to size their stories?

Actual Estimation & Relative Estimation

Getting Down to Work

What do Scrum Teams use to visually represent their project?

Information radiators

The Scrum Team must always work their stories in priority order.

FALSE

The PO can add a new story to a Sprint that the Team is currently in.

FALSE

All of the following are TRUE about the Daily Scrum except _.

  • everyone stands up ✓
  • it lasts 15 minnutes ✓
  • everyone answers the same 3 questions ✓
  • it lasts 30 minutes ✗

Wrapping Up a Sprint

Retrospective

The Team demonstrates the work they haven’t tested yet.

FALSE

This key Scrum role is the only one that can accept a story as done.

Product Owner

Why do Scrum Teams hold Retrospectives after every sprint?

to recognize how they can improve their work practices
